response: In the latest update in the ongoing 2021 Taliban offensive in Afghanistan, the group has captured Zaranj, the provincial capital of Nimruz Province. This marks the first major capture of a provincial city by the group since the 2001 invasion. The Taliban's victory was attributed to the lack of reinforcements from the central government military. A spokesperson for the local police confirmed that the city is now under Taliban control. This development further highlights the deteriorating security situation in the country. The Taliban has been making rapid territorial gains in recent months, capturing dozens of districts and provincial capitals amid the withdrawal of foreign forces. The group's latest victory underscores the urgency of the situation, with fears growing that the Taliban could seize more provincial capitals and possibly even Kabul, the capital city.

Recent wildfires in Greece have caused more devastating effects, including mass evacuations in northern Athens, and the deaths of at least two people - a volunteer firefighter who died from a fallen electricity pylon, and another man who died in a factory. More than 20 individuals have been injured, and dozens of homes have been burned in the areas of Attica, Olympia, Messenia, and Euboea. These unfortunate events have occurred amidst an unprecedented heatwave that has affected the country's weather conditions, and authorities are doing their best to evacuate villages and towns to ensure the safety of its citizens.

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in Queensland has prompted another snap lockdown in Cairns and Yarrabah, following news of an "unexpected" COVID-19 case. The infected person is a taxi driver from Kanimbla who had been infectious in Far North Queensland for 10 days. The three-day lockdown is aimed at slowing down the spread of the virus while contact tracing is conducted. This latest outbreak highlights the importance of continued vigilance in adhering to public health measures to prevent further outbreaks and keep the number of COVID-19 cases low.

Palau, a country in the western Pacific Ocean, has achieved herd immunity against COVID-19 as 80% of its population aged 12 and above have been vaccinated. The country receives vaccines from Operation Warp Speed and began vaccinating its citizens on 3 January 2021. As of 26 May 2021, the country estimated that 96% of adults have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19, about 70% of all Palauans. Teenagers aged 12 to 17 are also set to receive vaccines as tourism reopens in the country. In May, Palau established travel bubbles with Taiwan and Guam, allowing tourists to visit with restrictions. The first COVID-19 case was registered on 31 May 2021 and a second case on 11 June 2021. Despite the cases, Palau remains one of the few countries in the world to achieve herd immunity against COVID-19.

Egypt and Russia have a long history of diplomatic relations dating back to before the 16th century when it was centered on Russia's support for the Greek Orthodox Church of Alexandria. In recent years, the relationship has improved following the removal of Mohamed Morsi from office, with both countries working closely to strengthen military and trade ties, among other aspects of bilateral cooperation. In November 2015, Egypt and Russia signed a deal which would allow Russian and Egyptian warplanes to use each other's airbases and airspace. On December 11, 2017, during President Vladimir Putin's visit to Cairo, the two countries signed agreements in which Russia would build Egypt's first nuclear reactor, and supply nuclear fuel for the same. Russia supports Syrian government in the Syrian civil war, and intervened militarily in its favor in 2015, while Egypt openly backs the House of Representatives in the ongoing Libyan Civil War. In summer 2020, Egypt received five Su-35 jets, despite the American threatening with sanctions, and the direct commercial flights between Russia and Egypt have resumed for the first time since the Metrojet Flight 9268 bombing in 2015.

The ongoing 2021 Algeria wildfires have now killed 65 people, comprising of 37 civilians and 28 soldiers, with a total of 69 fires raging for four consecutive days. The Kabyle region and other areas have been severely affected, with Algerian authorities sending soldiers to aid citizens with evacuations and battling the blazes. The fires have had a devastating impact on the environment, with many Mediterranean trees destroyed, including olive trees, and the loss of cattle and chickens. Several villages have been hit hard by the fires, with limited access to water, and some residents attempting to fend off the flames themselves using rudimentary tools. The lack of firefighting aircraft has made the situation worse. President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has announced three days of national mourning for the victims of the wildfires.

The ongoing Lebanese liquidity crisis, which began in August 2019, continues to worsen due to recent developments. In response to the country's economic crisis, the Central Bank of Lebanon has ended fuel subsidies, instead offering credit lines for fuel imports at market price for the Lebanese pound. This move has sparked concerns of a significant increase in fuel prices in a nation already experiencing a major economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the 2020 Beirut port explosion, further exacerbating the situation. With shortages of US dollars, Lebanese citizens have already been facing steep inflation and difficulties accessing their savings in banks. Experts warn that without much-needed structural reforms, the economic crisis in Lebanon could become one of the three most severe since the mid-19th century.

Canada is set to hold a federal election on September 20, 2021, after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau obtained the dissolution of the House of Commons. The Canada Elections Act fixed-date provision requires federal elections to be held on the third Monday in October in the fourth calendar year after the previous election, but a minority government can be dissolved early. In the 2019 federal election, the Liberals lost their majority but won the most seats, with the Conservatives as the Official Opposition and the Bloc Québécois as the third party. Andrew Scheer later resigned as Conservative leader, and Erin O'Toole was elected as his successor. Elizabeth May also resigned as Green Party leader, with Annamie Paul succeeding her. With the latest election call, Canadians will have the opportunity to choose members of the House of Commons for the 44th Canadian Parliament.

The ongoing Panjshir conflict, a political dispute between the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan and the Taliban following the Fall of Kabul in 2021, has seen new developments as of September 2021. According to Russian intelligence sources, the Panjshir resistance forces loyal to Amrullah Saleh successfully re-captured Charikar and its surrounding areas in Parwan Province from the Taliban. The Islamic Republic of Afghanistan currently exercises de facto control over the Panjshir Valley, making it the only region out of the Taliban's hands. Previously, Saleh had declared himself as the President of Afghanistan from the Panjshir Valley and vowed to continue military operations against the Taliban from there, which was endorsed by Ahmad Massoud and Islamic Republic of Afghanistan Minister of Defence Bismillah Mohammadi. As of September 2021, no military conflict had occurred in Panjshir Province, but resistance forces continue to hold their ground in the face of increasing Taliban pressure.

The 2021 Niger attacks continue to escalate with the recent attack by gunmen on a mosque in the village of Theim, in southwestern Niger. The attack killed 16 people who were praying at the mosque, adding to the previous attacks that have left 439 people dead and over 100 others injured in Niger's western region of Tillabéri. The attacks have been frequent and ongoing, occurring every month of 2021, with the deadliest attacks being against civilians. The exact terrorist organization behind the attacks is still unclear, but Islamist militants believed to have crossed the border from Mali have been identified as the perpetrators. As the government of Niger continues to dispatch soldiers to border regions, newly elected President Mohamed Bazoum has declared three days of national mourning and condemned the attacks.

Operation Allies Refuge is a U.S. military operation to evacuate Afghan civilians, particularly interpreters, embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants from Afghanistan, as well as to assist NATO and regional allies in their respective evacuation efforts at Kabul International Airport. Announced on July 14 by the Biden administration, the operation has been ongoing and concurrent with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan. As of the announcement by United States Army Major General William D. Taylor, the U.S. has evacuated approximately 17,000 people, including 2,500 Americans, in the past few weeks. These efforts have involved the deployment of thousands of U.S. troops to Kabul International Airport and the expansion of the military presence from nearly 6,000 to its current level, with the activation of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation. However, the situation remains fraught with danger, with at least eight people killed at the airport as thousands of people try to forcibly board planes, including incidents in which people have fallen to their deaths from the sky or have been run over by departing planes. The future of evacuations from Afghanistan remains uncertain as the Taliban continue to take control over much of the country.

Operation Allies Refuge is an ongoing United States military operation to airlift selected at-risk Afghan civilians, particularly interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, from Afghanistan. U.S. personnel also assisted NATO and regional allies in their respective evacuation efforts at Kabul International Airport. The operation is concurrent with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan. The operation's name was officially unveiled on July 14 by the Biden administration. On August 22, the Department of Defense ordered the activation of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet for the third time, sending 18 planes that will be used to help evacuate American citizens. By August 20, the Pentagon said they had evacuated about 12,700 people from the country, and various commercial airline pilots and crews will help transport thousands of Afghans who are arriving at U.S. bases in Bahrain, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates. From the bases in the Middle East, the airliners would augment military flights carrying Afghans to Germany, Italy, Spain and other stops in Europe, and then ultimately to the United States. However, at least eight people had been killed at Kabul International Airport as thousands of people tried to forcibly board planes, including people who fell from departing C-17 cargo planes and at least three people who were killed after being run over. The Pentagon said that two armed men who fired into a crowd were killed by U.S. troops.

Operation Allies Refuge is a United States military operation aimed at airlifting at-risk Afghan civilians from Afghanistan, including interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants. The operation is being conducted concurrently with the American military withdrawal from Afghanistan, and its name was officially unveiled on July 14 by the Biden administration. On August 22, the Department of Defense ordered the activation of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation efforts, which includes commercial airline pilots and crews to transport thousands of Afghans from U.S. bases in the Middle East to European countries and eventually the United States. Fox News CEO Suzanne Scott announced on August 25 that the network had evacuated 24 people from Afghanistan, including three Afghan nationals who assisted with the network's coverage of the war. As of August 20, the Pentagon reported that roughly 12,700 people had been evacuated from the country, with concerns for the safety and well-being of those who remain.

Operation Allies Refuge is an ongoing United States military operation to evacuate at-risk Afghan civilians, particularly interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, from Afghanistan. The operation is concurrent with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan. The operation's name was officially unveiled on July 14 by the Biden administration. On August 22, the Department of Defense ordered the activation of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation. The current activation is for 18 planes from various commercial airlines, which would help transport thousands of Afghans who are arriving at U.S. bases in Bahrain, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates. From the bases in the Middle East, the airliners would augment military flights carrying Afghans to Europe and then ultimately to the United States. U.S. President Joe Biden says that American troops may remain in Afghanistan beyond the August 31 deadline. He also announced that 11,000 people were evacuated from the country in the past 36 hours, bringing the total number of people evacuated from Afghanistan to around 116,000.

The Panjshir conflict between the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan controlled by the Taliban and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, including the Panjshir resistance, continues as the Panjshir Valley remains the only region out of the Taliban's control. Led by Ahmad Massoud and self-proclaimed acting president Amrullah Saleh, the resistance refuses to surrender and claims war is "unavoidable" if the Taliban refuses dialogue on the formation of a comprehensive government. The population of the Panjshir Valley, consisting mostly of ethnic Tajik people, continues to defend the valley, which is known for its natural defenses against invaders. The resistance has reportedly gained access to helicopters formerly used by the Afghan military and is estimated to have gathered around 9,000 fighters in the valley. The situation has attempted to be resolved with the possibility of including the Taliban in a coalition government or by reaching a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but the resistance rejects the Taliban's refusal to negotiate. Meanwhile, the USA and Western forces remain lowly supportive of this movement as they prioritize the evacuation of Kabul, dependent on the Taliban's benevolence.

Operation Allies Refuge is an ongoing United States military operation that aims to airlift at-risk Afghan civilians, including interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, out of Afghanistan. The operation, which coincides with the larger American military withdrawal from the country, has been ongoing since July 14, when it was officially named by the Biden administration. However, amidst the deteriorating security situation in Afghanistan, the mission has faced critical challenges, including on August 26, when a security guard was killed, and three more people were wounded in a gunfight between an unknown gunman and Afghan forces at Kabul airport's north gate, involving German and American forces. Despite the challenges, U.S. personnel, as well as NATO and regional allies, continue to evacuate people from the country. As of August 22, approximately 17,000 people, including 2,500 Americans, had been evacuated from the country, and on August 22, the Department of Defense activated the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation.

The 2021 Niger attacks continue with militants targeting civilians and soldiers in Niger, particularly in the western region of Tillabéri. So far, the attacks have resulted in the deaths of more than 500 people and left over 100 injured. The attacks began earlier this year with the January and March attacks being the deadliest against civilians in the country. The death toll for the most recent August attacks has reached 53 with gunmen opening fire against civilians while they were praying at a mosque and attacking a village where civilians were tending their fields. In addition to the attacks in August, Boko Haram militants attacked a military post in Diffa, killing 16 soldiers and wounding nine others, leading to the death of 50 Islamist insurgents in the ensuing gun battle. The terrorists' main area of operation is the Sahel, and their attacks have left hundreds of thousands displaced and created a humanitarian crisis in the region.

On August 26, 2021, a suicide bombing near Abbey Gate at Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, Afghanistan killed at least 90 Afghan civilians and 13 American servicemembers, while more than 150 others were injured. The terrorist group ISIL-KP has claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred after the United States State Department advised Americans outside of the airport to leave due to a threat. The attack is suspected to have been coordinated by the group, which has threatened the airport in recent days. Since the fall of Afghanistan into Taliban control on August 15, 2021, Hamid Karzai International Airport has been the only secure way out of Afghanistan. Security concerns were heightened after hundreds of ISIS-K members escaped from jails at Bagram and Pul-e-Charkhi, which resulted in a warning from US diplomats in Kabul hours before the attack. Embassies from the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia had also warned about security threats. This attack has caused an international outcry with French President Emmanuel Macron already voicing his support for coordinating with “American allies” in response to the explosions. The attack has sparked a global response against the growing threat of terrorism in the region.

After the Taliban regained control of Afghanistan and announced their intentions to re-establish the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, the United States conducted an airstrike against an ISIL-KP member in Nangarhar Province on August 27, 2021. Recently, the US launched another airstrike in Nangarhar, killing two Islamic State members and injuring a third. According to reports, one of those killed had been planning additional attacks in Kabul. In the initial strike, the man targeted was believed to have planned the 2021 Kabul airport attack, and the use of an MQ-9 Reaper drone with guided munitions was meant to minimize civilian casualties. However, there is no known evidence of any civilian casualties in either of the airstrikes.

On 26 August 2021, a suicide bombing at Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, Afghanistan rocked the world and resulted in the deaths of at least 182 people, including 13 members of the United States military and 169 Afghan civilians. The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Khorasan Province (ISIL-KP) claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred during the evacuation from Afghanistan after the Taliban gained control of the country. In the following days, both the United States and the United Kingdom launched evacuation efforts while condemning the attack, and the US also launched an airstrike against an ISIL-KP member in Nangarhar Province on 27 August, killing two members and wounding a third. One of the deceased attackers was planning more attacks in Kabul.

Relations between the United States and the Taliban have been strained since August 15, 2021, when the Taliban returned to power after the fall of Kabul. The United States does not recognize the Taliban as a legitimate government, but has stated that they could recognize a government that respected basic rights. On August 27, the Taliban appointed Khalil Haqqani, a known terrorist with a $5 million bounty on his head, as head of security in Kabul. In response to the August 26 airport attack, the Taliban condemned the attack and vowed to capture ISIS-K leader Shahab al-Muhajir. The United States responded with an airstrike on August 27, killing two high-profile ISIS targets and injuring a third person. This led to condemnation from the Taliban, who viewed it as a "clear attack on Afghan territory."

Upon the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan and declaration of re-establishing the Islamic Emirate, multiple drone strikes occurred in the country. In one instance, a U.S. airstrike targeted a vehicle driven by an aid worker for U.S.-based Nutrition and Education International, resulting in the deaths of at least 10 people, including seven children, who were predominantly area residents. Some of those killed possessed visas for entry into the United States and had previously worked for international organizations. Reports indicate that additional civilians may have fallen victim to the attack. These actions come following the 2021 Kabul airport attack, which resulted in the loss of over 180 lives.

The Panjshir conflict between the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, controlled by the Taliban, and the Panjshir resistance, led by the National Resistance Front of Afghanistan, continues as the Taliban attempt to take control of the valley. The Panjshir resistance claims to have killed eight Taliban members in recent clashes. The valley is the last stronghold outside of Taliban control, and negotiations are currently underway in an attempt to reach a peaceful resolution to the conflict. The Panjshir resistance is seeking a decentralized government that ensures equal rights across the country as a condition for peace.

The Panjshir conflict has escalated with the entry of the Taliban into the valley and clashes with the National Resistance Front of Afghanistan forces who are led by Ahmad Massoud. Both sides report heavy casualties, and the Taliban claims to have gained some territory. The population of the Panjshir valley comprises a majority of ethnic Tajik people, while the Taliban are predominantly Pashtuns. The valley is well-known for its natural defences, making it challenging for the Taliban and the Soviet Union during the 1980s invasion and the Taliban during the 1990s civil war. The Taliban currently controls most of Afghanistan, while the former Islamic Republic of Afghanistan exercises de facto control over the Panjshir Valley, which is contiguous with Panjshir Province. As of August 2021, the valley is the only region not under Taliban control. Several local militias have also begun to fight the Taliban on their own, independent of the Panjshir-based forces. As of September 2021, the conflict remains ongoing.

Operation Allies Refuge was a US military operation aimed at airlifting at-risk Afghan civilians, including interpreters, US embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants. Concurrent with the broader American military withdrawal from Afghanistan, the initiative culminated with the evacuation of all eligible foreigners and vulnerable Afghans. Under the operation, SIV applicants were airlifted to the US, where they were temporarily housed by the US military until they could complete their SIV requirements. The mission's name was unveiled on July 14, 2021, by the Biden administration, and on July 22, the US House of Representatives passed the Averting Loss of Life and Injury by Expediting SIVs (ALLIES) Act to expedite the Afghan SIV process, including increasing the visa cap for Afghan interpreters. On August 31, the withdrawal deadline elapsed with around 100 Americans remaining in Afghanistan. According to White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain, the Biden administration's priority in Afghanistan remains to secure the safe return of those Americans.

On September 7th at 20:47 local time, a Mw 7.0 earthquake hit Guerrero, just outside Acapulco, Mexico. The earthquake, which was thrust faulting event located on the subduction zone boundary of the Caribbean Plate and Cocos Plate, had an estimated intensity of VII on the MMI scale and left more than 1.6 million without electricity. Sadly, one person was killed in Coyuca de Benítez due to a falling pole, and a few buildings in Acapulco were damaged, along with numerous reported gas leaks. There was also a recorded tsunami measuring 1.2 feet or 0.37 meters in Acapulco. It's worth noting that this event occurred on the anniversary of the 2017 Chiapas earthquake, which measured Mw 8.2 and killed at least 100 people. As the mayor of Acapulco, Adela Roman, urges residents to remain calm, ongoing assessments will evaluate the damage and seek to help those affected.

The United States military operation, Operation Allies Refuge, aimed to airlift at-risk Afghan civilians, including interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants out of Afghanistan. Concurrent with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan and the evacuation of all eligible foreigners and vulnerable Afghans, SIV applicants were airlifted to the United States, where they were temporarily housed by the U.S. military while they completed their SIV requirements. On 22 July, the Averting Loss of Life and Injury by Expediting SIVs (ALLIES) Act was passed by the United States House of Representatives, increasing the visa cap for Afghan interpreters and expediting the Afghan SIV process. As of September 7, more than 122,000 people have been evacuated from Afghanistan, including 21 Americans who were recently evacuated, according to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken. However, the United States is still working to extract more Americans and vulnerable Afghans from the country. The evacuation process was marred by tragedy, including a deadly suicide bombing attack that killed more than 180 people and wounded over 200 others, and the deaths of at least six individuals who attempted to flee the country as stowaways.

Since January 2001, the United States government has conducted multiple drone strikes in Afghanistan. These strikes began during the administration of the United States President George W. Bush and have continued through Donald Trump's presidency, with estimations suggesting that drone strikes increased four to five times compared with Barack Obama's presidency. However, a recent drone strike in August 2021 near Kabul International Airport, intended to target ISIL-K militants, instead killed 10 civilians, according to Marine Corps General Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr. This incident has added to the criticism the United States government has faced for the number of unintended civilian casualties resulting from drone strikes. As of 2021, there have been at least 13,074 airstrikes conducted by the US government, resulting in at least 4,138 deaths, including 310 civilians and 73 children.

On September 18, 2021, a rally was held near the United States Capitol in support of the people who were arrested and charged for their involvement in the insurrection on January 6. The event was held amid fears of potential violence, and a fence was erected around the building. Despite the concerns, only a small crowd of around 400 to 450 people attended, and four participants were arrested for various felonies, including possession of weapons. Republicans largely distanced themselves from the event, and far-right groups like the Proud Boys urged their members not to attend. The rally was seen as a show of solidarity for those facing legal consequences for their actions in the Capitol attack.

On September 19, 2021, police were dispatched to a residential property on Chandos Crescent in Killamarsh, Derbyshire, where they discovered the remains of three children and one adult, dead. The incident has since been identified as a suspected mass murder, and authorities have charged 31-year-old Damien Bendall of Killamarsh with four counts of murder in connection with the crime. The town of Killamarsh is an outer suburb of Sheffield, South Yorkshire, and is a former coal mining town that has expanded with the growth of the city to the south and east. The victims of the tragedy have been identified as Lacey Bennett (aged 11), John Paul Bennett (aged 13), their mother Terri Harris (aged 35), and Lacey's friend Connie Gent (aged 11), who was staying with the family for a sleepover.  The investigation continues.

On September 25, 2021, an Amtrak passenger train derailed outside the town of Joplin, Montana, resulting in at least three deaths and roughly 50 injuries. The train was en route with 147 passengers and 13 crew members when the accident occurred at approximately 4:00 p.m. MT. The victims were taken to hospitals for medical attention. The cause of the derailment remains under investigation.

On October 2, 2021, Qatar held its first-ever legislative elections in which Qataris voted to elect 30 out of 45 members of the Consultative Assembly. Originally scheduled for 2013, the elections were postponed twice, but finally came to fruition following an announcement by Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani in November 2020. While political parties remain prohibited, 284 candidates including 29 women ran as independents for the single-member constituencies using the first-past-the-post voting system. However, eligibility criteria became a point of controversy with the law limiting voting to Qatari nationals with 1930 citizenry or earlier, thus barring naturalized citizens, Al Murrah tribe members and their descendants from participating in the elections, sparking protests. Nonetheless, the elections represent a major step forward for the country in terms of democratic reforms.

On 3 October 2021, tragedy struck when a Pilatus PC-12 plane crashed into an empty building in San Donato Milanese, Lombardy, Italy, resulting in the death of all eight individuals on board. The private jet accident devastated families of those affected and shocked the local community. Investigations into the cause of the crash are ongoing.

The Pandora Papers, released by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists on October 3, 2021, contain 11.9 million leaked documents that expose instances of hidden wealth, tax evasion and money laundering among a wide range of public figures, including 330 politicians, 35 national leaders, and 130 billionaires. The documents reveal a total of 29,000 beneficiaries across 27,000 companies—making it the largest offshore data leak in history, surpassing the Panama Papers by half a million documents. Among the revelations were Tony Blair's purchase of a £6.45 million property in London using a British Virgin Islands company to save £312,000 on Stamp Duty. Although not illegal, such transactions raise questions about the ethical dimensions of offshore tax evasion.

The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) has published 11.9 million leaked documents, revealing hidden wealth, tax evasion, and money laundering among 330 politicians, including 35 national leaders, and numerous celebrities worldwide, including 130 billionaires, worth up to an estimated $32 trillion. The data leak is the largest offshore leak in history, exceeding the Panama Papers by nearly half a million documents. The documents were published by the ICIJ and describe their most expansive exposé of financial secrecy yet, containing documents from 14 financial service companies in Panama, Switzerland, and the UAE. The individuals named in the leak include former British Prime Minister Tony Blair, Chilean President Sebastián Piñera, Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta, Montenegrin President Milo Đukanović, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim, Gabonese President Ali Bongo Ondimba, and Ecuadorian President Guillermo Lasso. The leaked files come from offshore service providers that help clients establish companies in secrecy jurisdictions, and the ICIJ worked with journalists in 117 countries, including news organizations such as The Washington Post, L'Espresso, Le Monde, El País, Süddeutsche Zeitung, PBS program Frontline, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, The Guardian, and the BBC's Panorama.

On October 4, 2021, Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Oculus suffered an extended global outage beginning at 15:39 UTC. The cause of the outage was attributed to a potential BGP update from Facebook, as per some experts. The disruption has affected millions of users across the globe, and other social media platforms like Twitter faced difficulties as users flocked to their platforms during the outage. The situation is ongoing, and there is no clarity on when the services will resume.

A 5.9 magnitude earthquake struck Harnai, Balochistan, Pakistan on 7 October 2021, leaving at least 24 people dead and around 200 others injured. The earthquake occurred during the rupture of a thrust fault under the Sulaiman Mountains and Central Brāhui Range, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. Troops from the Pakistan Army were dispatched to aid in rescue and relief operations, with medical personnel, response workers, and officials working together to coordinate the efforts. The earthquake occurred near the anniversary of the 2005 Kashmir earthquake, which killed over 87,000 people - and comes after a major tremor in the region that occurred nearby in 2013, killing at least 800 people. Oblique convergence between the Indian Plate and Eurasian Plate made Pakistan directly influenced, involving the large Chaman Fault that caused earthquakes in the region, including the 2005 earthquake.

UPDATED VERSION:

On 13 October 2021, a man using a bow and arrow killed five people and injured two others in the streets of Kongsberg, Viken, Norway. The attack took place in several locations before the perpetrator was arrested. The incident left the town in shock and mourning. The authorities are investigating the motive behind the attack, and the community is mourning the loss of life caused by this senseless act of violence.

On 13 October 2021, a 37-year-old Norwegian man and convert to Islam with Danish citizenship, identified as Espen Andersen Bråthen, carried out a deadly attack in Kongsberg, Viken, Norway, killing five people and injuring three more using a bow and arrow. Police had been concerned about his radicalization, and he had several prior criminal convictions for break-ins, cannabis possession, and threats against family members. The suspect was first spotted walking around Kongsberg with a bow and arrows on his shoulder, and upon receiving the first calls, a patrol was sent to the location of the attack, followed by three others. Armed officers first confronted the perpetrator six minutes after the first calls, but he fired several arrows at them and escaped. He then launched the attack and killed his victims in different locations. The attack was the deadliest in Norway since the 2011 attacks committed by Anders Behring Breivik. The suspect has confessed to the attack and is being held in police custody.

On 15 October 2021, a suicide bombing took place during Friday prayers at the Imam Bargah mosque, a Shia mosque in Kandahar, Afghanistan, resulting in the deaths of at least 65 individuals and injuring over 70 others. A statement from Amaq, the media arm of the Islamic State – Khorasan Province, took responsibility for the attack. This bombing happened a week following another bombing, likewise claimed by the Islamic State – Khorasan Province, at a Shia mosque in Kunduz, which led to the death of around 50 people. After these two incidents, the Taliban has announced that they will implement tighter security measures at Shi'ite mosques to prevent further bombings, considering the death toll close to 120.

Sir David Amess, a long-serving member of the British Conservative Party and Member of Parliament for Southend West, was declared a victim of a terrorist incident by law enforcement officials after being stabbed to death in a Methodist Church in Leigh-on-Sea, Essex. The attack occurred during a constituency meeting on October 15, 2021, with a 25-year-old man quickly arrested on the scene on suspicion of murder. Amess was a prominent politician who held no senior positions but was an "instantly recognizable" member of the Conservative Party, notably opposing abortion and campaigning for Brexit, amongst other centrist views. His murder has shocked the political world and led to renewed calls to review the security provided to elected officials during public engagements. Prime Minister Boris Johnson ordered a complete security review for all MPs in light of the attack. BBC One was one of the media outlets that paid respect to Amess, changing their evening schedule in lieu of the tragic event.

Protests in Kosovo by the Kosovo Serbs against the government's decision to ban Serbian license plates have come to an end, following an agreement reached in Brussels on 30 September 2021. The ban triggered protests, mostly consisting of blocking traffic near border crossings, and led to the worsening of relations between Serbia and Kosovo. On 2 October, according to the agreement, barricades set up by protesters were removed, and traffic blocks ended, leading to border traffic resuming. A working group consisting of negotiators from the governments of Kosovo and Serbia will meet in Brussels on 21 October 2021, to find a more permanent solution to the license plate issue. If negotiations are successful, the group will announce their proposals in 6 months. Concerns remain about the escalating tensions between the two countries, with international powers calling for de-escalation.

On 15 October 2021, Sir David Amess, a British Conservative Party politician and Member of Parliament (MP) for Southend West, was tragically stabbed to death multiple times during a political surgery at the Belfairs Methodist Church Hall in Leigh-on-Sea, Essex. Ali Harbi Ali, a 25-year-old male British citizen, was arrested and later charged with murder and the preparation of terrorist acts. In a recent update, Ali appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court and the Old Bailey after being charged with Amess' murder and has been remanded to Belmarsh prison. Ali's trial is set for March 7, 2022. Amess was an instantly recognisable member of the Conservative Party and had been knighted for his political and public service. He was a devout Catholic and a socially conservative politician known for opposing abortion, supporting capital punishment, and campaigning in favour of Brexit. His death triggered a by-election to fill his former seat in Parliament, and numerous tributes were paid to him by politicians and the public alike.

Solar cycle 25 began in December 2019 with a smoothed minimum sunspot number of 1.8 and is expected to continue until about 2030. Although there were widely varying predictions regarding the strength of the cycle ranging from very weak to strong, the Solar Cycle 25 Prediction Panel predicted in December 2019 that it will be similar to solar cycle 24, with the number of sunspots reaching a (smoothed) maximum of 115 in July 2025 (± 8 months). Early signs of the new cycle include the appearance of reversed polarity sunspots and polarward reversed polarity sunspots since as early as December 2016, as well as the brewing of magnetic regions with the underlying orientation of solar cycle 25 toroidal field component observed in December 2019. Recently, an X-class solar flare, the second of the cycle, erupted which could graze Earth on October 30 or 31, accompanied by possible bright aurorae and potential interference with satellite communications. The first C-class solar flares took place on May 29, 2020, with activity increasing in the following months, especially abruptly in October, with flares taking place on a near-daily basis by November. On November 29, an M4.4 flare, the strongest of the cycle to date, took place, possibly indicating the solar cycle would be more active than initially thought. A small coronal mass ejection was found heading directly towards Earth on December 8, 2020, shortly after a strong C-class solar flare, causing bright aurorae at high latitudes.

The 2021 G20 Rome summit, which takes place on 30-31 October in Rome, Italy, is the sixteenth meeting of Group of Twenty (G20). This year, the event marks the first in-person gathering since the beginning of the pandemic, and it includes a mix of in-person and virtual presence. The summit features participations from leaders of the 20 member countries, including Australia's Prime Minister, Scott Morrison, Brazil's President, Jair Bolsonaro, and Canada's Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau. Notably, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping are joining the summit via video link. The event also invites some additional world leaders as invited guests, including Mark Rutte, the Prime Minister of the Netherlands. The summit aims to address pressing issues around climate change, economic recovery, and vaccine distribution.

UPDATED VERSION:

On 31 October 2021, a collision between two trains occurred near Salisbury railway station in Wiltshire, resulting in a derailment and leaving seventeen people injured. The incident took place around 7:00 pm UTC at Fisherton Tunnel near London Road. Emergency response teams, including police and firefighters, immediately arrived at the scene to attend to the injured. Following preliminary investigations, authorities are working to determine the cause of the collision between the two trains.

UPDATED VERSION:

On Monday, November 1, 2021, tragedy struck in Lagos as a high-rise building that was under construction collapsed, resulting in at least 15 fatalities and several others being trapped. Located in the Ikoyi neighborhood, the 22-story building was in the midst of construction when it crumbled. This news comes as a shocking update to the previously reported incident where three people were confirmed dead. Authorities are still investigating the cause of the collapse and working to rescue anyone still trapped under the debris. Our thoughts and prayers go out to the families and loved ones affected by this devastating event.

On November 2, 2021, a horrific insurgent attack took place at the Daoud Khan Military Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan. The attack started with a bomb explosion at the entrance of the hospital, followed by a second explosion and heavy gunfire that caused more than 25 casualties and wounded over 50 others. The Taliban claimed responsibility for killing four attackers and taking one into custody. Shockingly, the Islamic State – Khorasan Province is said to have carried out the attack. The Taliban believes that the goal of the insurgents was to attack the military leadership present at the hospital, but they narrowly missed their mark, and this brings another wave of insecurity and instability in Afghanistan.

On 1 November 2021, a 21-story luxury residential high-rise collapsed in Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria. The building, part of the "360 Degrees Towers" trio of high-rise buildings, was being constructed by United Kingdom-based private development company, Fourscore Homes. The Lagos State Building Control Agency had only approved 15 floors, but 21 stories had already been built. At least 22 people have died, and an uncertain number are believed to still be trapped in the rubble as search-and-rescue operations continue into the third day. Femi Osibona, the head of Fourscore Homes, was reportedly inside the building during the collapse and is still missing. The building's owner has been arrested and will be prosecuted, and the chief architect has been suspended while the state government conducts an investigation. The collapse has raised serious concerns about the safety of building sites in Nigeria.

On November 2, 2021, incumbent Democratic Governor Phil Murphy won his re-election bid, defeating Republican former state legislator Jack Ciattarelli. This victory makes Murphy the first Democrat to be re-elected as New Jersey governor since Brendan Byrne in 1977. The general election saw five candidates on the ballot, with Murphy winning the Democratic nomination unopposed and facing Ciattarelli, Green nominee Madelyn Hoffman, Libertarian nominee Gregg Mele, and SWP nominee Joanne Kuniansky. Despite a cancelled debate between Ciattarelli and Hirsh Singh, the election saw intense campaigning and fundraising efforts from both candidates, with Murphy ultimately emerging victorious.

On 1 November 2021, a 21-story luxury residential high-rise tower collapsed in Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria. It was one of the "360 Degrees Towers," which were being constructed by Fourscore Homes, a UK-registered company headed by experienced Nigerian developer Femi Osibona. The Lagos State Building Control Agency had approved only 15 floors, but 21 had been built. The death toll from the collapse has increased to 36, with many more still trapped in the rubble. A rescue effort is ongoing and being supervised by the Commissioner for Special Duties and Intergovernmental Relations, and the Lagos State Ministry of Physical Planning and Urban Development. The state government has suspended the chief architect, and an independent panel has been allotted 30 days to disclose findings. Fourscore Homes' owner has been arrested and will be prosecuted.

On November 5, 2021, a collision between an oil tanker and a truck in Freetown, Sierra Leone, resulted in a catastrophic explosion that killed at least 99 people and left over 100 injured. The incident took place in the Wellington suburb at a junction outside Choithram Supermarket. The accident is believed to have occurred at 22:00 GMT when the fuel truck spilled, followed by an ignition that triggered the explosion. Reports indicate that a bus full of passengers was "completely" burnt, and nearby markets and shops caught fire after fuel spilled onto the streets. The mortuary at Connaught Hospital has received 92 bodies, and the injured have been transferred to hospitals. President Julius Maada Bio has offered condolences and promised support to the victims' families, and Vice President Mohamed Juldeh Jalloh has visited two hospitals where hospital staff have reported stretched services. Freetown, Sierra Leone's port city with a population of over 1 million, has faced several disasters in the past, such as mudslides in 2017 that killed over 1,000 people and a major fire that left over 5000 displaced in March 2021.

On November 5, 2021, tragedy struck at the Astroworld Music Festival in Houston, Texas. The festival, operated by rapper Travis Scott, saw a stampede and crowd crush that resulted in the deaths of eight people and injuries for hundreds more. The cause of death is still under investigation, but drug overdose is being investigated as a potential cause of cardiac arrest for some victims. The festival, which had approximately 50,000 attendees, had 367 police officers and 241 security officers present, along with 55 in-service units from the Houston Fire Department. The festival's paramedics were seen performing CPR on unconscious attendees and more than 300 people were treated for injuries at the festival's field hospital. Scott and his staff paused the performance when he noticed attendees in distress near the stage, but he resumed the performance shortly after. The second night of the festival was cancelled and a reunification center was set up for families searching for relatives. The incident is under investigation, and Scott stated he would support the investigation and help heal the Houston community.

The United Arab Emirates and Syria have had diplomatic relations for years, with the former maintaining an embassy in Damascus and the latter having an embassy in Abu Dhabi and a consulate-general in Dubai. The two countries, which are both located in the Middle East, share close cultural ties. Recently, there was a historic meeting between Emirati Foreign Minister Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, marking the first time they have met since the beginning of the Syrian Civil War 10 years ago. During the meeting, they discussed ways to develop cooperation in various sectors that are of mutual interest.

On November 5, 2021, a fatal fuel tanker explosion occurred in Freetown, Sierra Leone, at the Wellington area's busy intersection, killing at least 101 people and injuring more than 100. The collision between the fuel tanker and a lorry triggered a blaze, and victims, including passengers in cars and a bus full of people, were trapped in the ensuing traffic chaos. The event led to extensive damage to nearby shops and markets, and many locals, particularly the "Okada" (motorbike) taxi-riders, attempted to collect the spilt petrol in containers, which worsened the damage. Rescue efforts at the scene ended on November 6, and the injured were transferred to hospitals, with some being in critical condition. Recently, the death toll has risen to 115. The tragic event highlights the risks of fuel tanker explosions in densely populated areas in sub-Saharan Africa, where spilled fuel is viewed as wasteful in communities where many struggle to afford petrol.

Israel, which has one of the highest vaccination rates per capita, has approved the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for children between the ages of 5 and 11 years old. The decision was made by the country's pandemic advisory board, following trials that showed the vaccine to be highly effective in preventing severe illness and hospitalization among children. With this move, Israel has become the first country to approve the Pfizer vaccine for children in this age group. The country has been a leader in vaccinating its population against COVID-19, having given at least one dose to around 64% of eligible Israelis as of June 26, 2021, and the recent approval for children will further strengthen their efforts to tackle the pandemic.

On 14 November 2021, at approximately 10:59 am GMT, an explosion occurred inside a taxi in the car park in front of the main entrance of the Liverpool Women's Hospital, which has now been declared a terrorist incident by police. The passenger, a man of Middle Eastern origin not known to MI5, was killed in the incident, having constructed the device himself, and the taxi driver, David Perry, was injured but released the following day. New information revealed by Mayor Joanne Anderson states that Perry locked the passenger inside the vehicle upon noticing that the bomber was wearing an explosive device. Merseyside Police made three arrests under the Terrorism Act and searched a property in the Sefton Park area, with three additional men being arrested in the Kensington area. On 15 November 2021, the police declared the explosion a terrorist incident, with the UK terror threat level being raised from substantial to severe. The incident has gained international attention, with reports from CNN, The New York Times, and The Washington Post.

On November 18, 2021, Tonga held general elections to choose 17 of the 26 seats in the Legislative Assembly of Tonga, with 73 candidates running for office. The previous general elections in 2017 resulted in the Democratic Party of the Friendly Islands winning by a considerable margin, and the late ʻAkilisi Pōhiva was re-elected as Prime Minister. However, after his death in 2019, Pohiva Tuʻiʻonetoa was elected to be the next Prime Minister with the support of the nobles, independent MPs, and five former members of DPFI. Although Democratic party leader Semisi Sika presented a motion of no-confidence against Prime Minister Tuʻiʻonetoa in December 2020, the Legislative Assembly rejected it on January 12, 2021. Despite a week-long lockdown due to a COVID-19 case, the polls went ahead as scheduled, and Tongans voted for their new government.

On November 23, 02:00 local time, tragedy struck in Western Bulgaria when a bus carrying Macedonian tourists returning from Istanbul crashed and caught fire near Bosnek, Pernik Province, resulting in the death of forty-six individuals with seven more sustaining injuries. The accident occurred on a motorway south-west of Sofia, sparking widespread devastation and anguish. We can only hope that those affected receive the support and care they need during this time of immense grief and loss.

The Solomon Islands has been engulfed in civil unrest for three days, with rioting, looting, and clashes with police. The Australian Federal Police have taken control of Honiara, the capital city, and implemented a curfew that begins at 7:00 p.m. local time. The protests began peacefully, but turned violent on 24 November 2021, with buildings being burnt down and schools and businesses closing. Most of the protesters came from Malaita province, which had recently held an illegitimate independence referendum that the national government dismissed. The cause of the civil unrest stems from the government's withdrawal of recognition of the Republic of China (Taiwan) in favor of establishing relations with mainland China, which has caused tension between different provinces in the country. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has resisted calls to resign and accused the protesters of being "politically motivated," while the premier of Malaita Province and the opposition leader have criticized the government's handling of the situation. China has expressed concern about the attacks and supports the Solomon Islands Government's attempts to restore order and stability quickly.

The 2021-2022 European windstorm season marks the seventh seasonal naming event in Europe for windstorms, with the Netherlands, Ireland, and the United Kingdom participating for the third season. The season also includes the collaborative efforts of the meteorological agencies of Portugal, Spain, France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Greece, Israel, Cyprus, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. Storms named by the agencies will be used interchangeably. The storms naming convention for the UK, Ireland, and the Netherlands is based on the National Severe Weather Warning Service, while other agencies, such as France, Spain, Portugal, and Belgium, have their naming scheme. Former Atlantic hurricanes will retain their original names as assigned by the National Hurricane Center of the US.  Most recently, Storm Arwen hit the British Isles, causing three fatalities and widespread damages and travel disruptions, with 100,000 people losing power in Scotland and North East England.

On November 30, 2021, a 15-year-old sophomore student opened fire on students at Oxford High School in the Detroit exurb of Oxford Township, Michigan, killing four students and injuring seven others. The suspected shooter has been identified and is in custody. Prior to the incident, there were threats of a mass shooting at the school, which had been investigated by school administrators but found none. The suspect reportedly used a semiautomatic handgun during the shooting, and the school went into lockdown with students being evacuated to a nearby Meijer store. Police arrived at the school and arrested the gunman without any problems. President Joe Biden and Representative Elissa Slotkin expressed their condolences over the shooting, while Governor Gretchen Whitmer called gun violence a "public health crisis."

The Semeru volcano on the Indonesian island of Java erupted on December 4, 2021, killing one person and injuring 41 others. The eruption sent a cloud of volcanic ash 40,000 feet (12,000 meters) into the air and triggered a pyroclastic flow that traveled down the slopes of the volcano. The collapse of a lava dome at the summit crater due to intense precipitation is thought to have triggered the eruption, which is part of a series of explosive eruptions beginning in 2014. The eruption affected six sub-districts in the Malang Regency and eight villages and two sub-districts in the Lumajang Regency, causing damage to bridges, roads, and buildings. Many people were displaced and provided with aid, while authorities urged residents to keep a safe distance from the volcano. Indonesian President Joko Widodo visited the affected areas to lead recovery efforts, while the Governor of East Java helped with the evacuation process.

On 4 December 2021, thirteen civilians were killed, including miners returning from work and a soldier, when soldiers of the Assam Rifles opened fire after mistaking them for militants. The incident took place in Nagaland, India, and resulted in public outrage and widespread condemnation, with calls to repeal and revoke the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (AFSPA). Angry locals also confronted the soldiers, leading to further violence that claimed the life of a soldier and seven more miners. The Special Investigation Team (SIT) was formed to probe the incident, while the National Human Rights Commission of India sent notices to the Central and the State governments.

The COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom continues to surge as the country reports a record-breaking 78,610 new cases in the past 24 hours. This increase in cases has been attributed to the highly transmissible Omicron variant of the virus, which has rapidly spread throughout the country despite high vaccination rates. In response to the surge in cases, the UK government has implemented stricter measures, including mandatory mask-wearing in public indoor spaces and a requirement for proof of vaccination status for entry to certain venues. The surge in cases has put a significant strain on the country's healthcare system and has further disrupted the economy and daily life for many citizens.

On 16 December 2021, the Liberal Democrats achieved a huge upset in the UK's House of Commons by-election for the North Shropshire constituency, an area in the West Midlands. The election was triggered by the resignation of Conservative MP Owen Paterson on 4 November. The Liberal Democrats candidate, Helen Morgan, won with a 34.1% swing, defeating the Conservative Party, which had held the seat since the constituency was created. Morgan is a chartered accountant who was born and raised in the rural West Midlands and has lived in North Shropshire since 2014. The swing was the 7th largest in United Kingdom by-election history. The constituency, the third-largest by area in the West Midlands region, includes five small towns: Wem, Whitchurch, Ellesmere, Oswestry, and Market Drayton. Sixty per cent of constituents had previously voted to leave the European Union in the 2016 EU referendum.

On 20 December 2021, a cargo ship named Francia with 138 people onboard sank off the northeast coast of Madagascar. It became vulnerable to wave action due to the engine room flooding caused by a hole in the ship's hull. The vessel had illegally taken on 130 passengers, and at least 85 people died in the accident. On 23 December, 24 more bodies were discovered, bringing the total death toll to 85. The Madagascan government immediately started an investigation into the sinking, and three vessels from the Madagascan navy and maritime agency assisted in the search for survivors. The accident also involved a helicopter crash, which killed one passenger and caused injuries to others, including the police minister. The tragic incident brought grief to the nation, and Madagascan president Andry Rajoelina paid tribute to those who died in the shipwreck and helicopter crash, saying that some bodies were sent to nearby villages for burial because the local graveyard was too small to accommodate them all.

The COVID-19 pandemic in South Australia continues to worsen, with the state reporting a record 744 new cases in the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 4,324. In response, the government has implemented a range of restrictions, including mandatory mask-wearing in high-risk settings and a ban on indoor dining. Schools have also been closed, and construction work halted. Despite the high case numbers, the state has started to ease restrictions as vaccination rates continue to climb, with borders reopening to other states in November and the adoption of a suppression strategy. The state has also been impacted by event cancellations, including the Tour Down Under bicycle race and the cancellation of the 2021 and 2022 Royal Adelaide Show due to COVID-19.

Record-breaking rainfall has caused severe flooding in the northeastern Brazilian state of Bahia leading to the deaths of 18 individuals. As of the 27th of December 2021, the floods have affected over 35,000 individuals, with 72 municipalities in the state of Bahia having declared a state of emergency. The state capital Salvador has received over 250 millimetres (9.8 inches) of rain on the 24th of December, which is five times the historical average. A joint rescue operation has been mounted by the Bahia state government and Brazilian federal government, with support from other state governments, to provide relief to those affected by the floods. The collapse of two dams in Jussiape and Itambe on the 25th and 26th of December respectively has further exacerbated the situation. This event follows the devastation caused earlier in the same month by Subtropical Storm Ubá, which had badly flooded southern Bahia.

Iran's involvement in cyberwarfare continues to be a pressing concern as suspected Iranian hackers have recently targeted the website of Israel's Jerusalem Post newspaper. The attack replaced the newspaper's content with a direct threat to Israel's Shimon Peres Negev Nuclear Research Center and a reference to Qasem Soleimani's assassination exactly two years earlier. Iran's "Cyber Defense Command" has been functioning since 2010, making the country an emerging military power in the field of cybersecurity. Reports suggest that Iran is one of the most active players in the international cyber arena, with its digital fortress and national information network developed to thwart attacks and engage attackers. While Iran denies launching cyberattacks against other countries, it has been accused of doing so by western analysts. Therefore, the threat of Iranian cyberattacks continues to pose a significant risk.

On January 9, 2022, a devastating fire engulfed a 19-story residential building in the Belmont neighborhood of the Bronx, New York City. The raging flames claimed the lives of 17 people and left 44 others injured. The incident is expected to be one of the worst fires in the modern history of New York City. Emergency services were called to the scene at dawn and were able to quell the blaze after several hours of intense firefighting. Investigations are currently underway to determine the cause of the fire, and officials say that the damage to the building was extensive, leaving many residents displaced and homeless.

The ongoing 2021-22 Russo-Ukrainian crisis continues to escalate as Ukraine recently announced the arrest of an alleged Russian intelligence agent. The agent is accused of attempting to recruit individuals to launch attacks in the port city of Odessa. Since late October 2021, tensions have increasingly risen between Russia and Ukraine, with the crisis causing international concern and involving the United States, NATO, the European Union, and the Commonwealth of Independent States. Reports of Russian troop buildups near the Ukrainian border have been a significant source of tension, with both sides trading accusations of aggression. Talks between Russia and the US are set to take place in Geneva on January 10th, and NATO has called for a reduction in tensions in the region. The situation remains volatile and unpredictable, with both sides continuing to make diplomatic and military moves.

The ongoing Russo-Ukrainian crisis, which began in late October 2021, continues to escalate as talks between NATO and Russia hit a breaking point. The crisis, which involves a military confrontation and international tension between Russia and Ukraine, has drawn in the United States, NATO, the European Union, and the Commonwealth of Independent States. Poland has warned of a possible war, adding to the tension in the region. The crisis was provoked by the first combat use of the Ukrainian Bayraktar TB2 UAV against the DPR formations, and reports suggest that Russia has amassed over 92,000 troops and Iskander short-range ballistic missile systems near the Ukrainian borders. The diplomatic and security talks have failed to alleviate the ongoing military escalation, as both sides continue to accuse each other of aggressive actions. The situation is worsening, and increasing calls for peace and de-escalation are being made amid fears of a potential war.

The 2022 Australian Open, which is set to take place from January 17 to January 30, 2022, is embroiled in controversy after the cancellation of defending champion Novak Djokovic's visa by the Australian Minister for Immigration and Citizenship, Alex Hawke, due to "health and good order grounds." Djokovic had previously been granted a medical exemption from mandatory COVID-19 vaccination by Tennis Australia and the health department of the state of Victoria but was detained by the Australian Border Force upon arrival on January 5 after his visa was found to not meet the country's entry requirements for unvaccinated travelers. Djokovic appealed the visa refusal, leading the Federal Circuit and Family Court to rule in his favor and order his release from detention on January 10. Despite this, the Australian government has now canceled his visa, causing uncertainty over his eligibility to compete in the tournament. The controversy has sparked public backlash in Australia, given the strict border requirements that many Australians are facing during the pandemic.

On January 15, 2022, an armed man claiming to be the brother of Pakistani Al-Qaeda suspect Aafia Siddiqui held congregants hostage at Congregation Beth Israel Synagogue in Colleyville, Texas. During the incident, which lasted for more than 12 hours, the man demanded that Siddiqui be released from prison, making anti-Israel comments and threatening to kill everyone in the building. Negotiations were attempted by law enforcement, and Rabbi Charlie Cytron-Walker was forced to call a New York-based rabbi to convey the assailant's demands. The situation ended when police shot and killed the suspect at around 11:30 p.m., and thankfully all four hostages, including Rabbi Cytron-Walker, were freed unharmed. The incident garnered national attention, and tributes and condemnations poured forth from many political leaders and religious figures around the world.

On 15 January 2022, a large eruption of Hunga Tonga, a volcanic island in Tonga in the Pacific Ocean, caused tsunamis in Tonga, Fiji, American Samoa, and Lambayeque, Peru. Tsunami warnings were issued in multiple countries including Fiji, Samoa, Vanuatu, New Zealand, Australia, Japan, the United States, Canada, Chile, Ecuador, and Peru. Two people were reportedly killed in Peru due to the small tsunami. The eruption, which began on 14 January 2022, sent clouds of ash 20 kilometres (12 mi) into the atmosphere and has caused a temporary climate effect according to scientists. The extent of damage and casualties in Tonga and other affected areas is still being assessed, and the Tongan government has not confirmed any casualties from the eruption and tsunami. Rescue operations are currently underway in Atata Island, off the main Tonga island near Nukuʻalofa, after the small island was reportedly submerged by the tsunami. The events in Tonga have prompted discussions in New Zealand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to provide aid to Tonga.

On January 20, 2022, a large-scale Islamic State attack occurred at Al-Sina'a prison in Al-Hasakah, Syria, resulting in the freeing of prisoners and intense clashes with Kurdish forces. The attack began with a car bomb and heavy gunfire aimed at the prison, which triggered a riot among the prisoners leading to the subsequent occupation of the prison by armed prisoners and the escape of several of them. The situation escalated, causing a spread of the Islamic State fighters to Al-Zouhour area and solidifying control of Al-Sina'a. The clashes continued into the next day, with forces of the International Coalition dispatched to offer support, while SDF forces tracked down and arrested 89 prisoners who had escaped. The situation claimed 67 lives through the various clashes, making it the largest attack by the Islamic State since losing its last key Syrian territory in 2019.

Singapore's COVID-19 vaccination campaign continues to evolve as new developments arise. Starting from March 14, the Ministry of Health has announced that eligible individuals aged 12 to 17 can receive a booster dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Singapore is currently the world's most-vaccinated country, with more than 88% of its population having completed their vaccination regimen, and the government has invested over one billion Singapore dollars to procure advanced vaccine candidates like Pfizer BioNTech, Moderna, and CoronaVac. The country's Expert Committee on COVID-19 Vaccination has recommended vaccination prioritization for high-risk individuals, such as healthcare workers and the elderly, as the pandemic continues. The recent expansion of booster shots to younger age groups will further bolster Singapore's efforts to achieve herd immunity and curb the spread of the virus.

On 25 January 2022, militants belonging to the Baluch Liberation Front launched an insurgent attack on a security post belonging to Pakistani military in a remote area of Dasht, Kech District in Balochistan, killing ten security personnel and injuring three others. The clash lasted for several hours, and the militants seized weapons from the post, but suffered significant casualties. The Pakistan Army has responded to the attack with a clearance operation, in which they killed one attacker and arrested three others. The Baluch Liberation Front has claimed responsibility for the attack, but no other group has taken responsibility.

UPDATED VERSION:

During the last few days of January and the beginning of February 2022, Ecuador was hit by severe rainfall that resulted in numerous landslides, floods, and mudflows. One of the most destructible events was a landslide that occurred in Quito, the capital city of Ecuador, which caused tremendous devastation and cost the lives of at least 23 people, leaving 9 still unaccounted for. Over 47 people were also injured in the natural disaster. The authorities are working tirelessly to provide aid to the affected areas and assist the survivors of this catastrophe.

On 1 February 2022, an attempted coup d\'état occurred in Guinea-Bissau and according to President Umaro Sissoco Embalo, "many" members of the security forces were killed in the "failed attack against democracy". The President assured AFP news agency that the situation was under control and that "all is well", but reports remain unclear about the fate of the government in Guinea-Bissau. The Economic Community of West African States and the African Union have condemned the coup attempt, urging the military to return to their barracks while mentioning that the military is responsible for the physical integrity of the President and the government officials.

On 2 February 2022, over 60 residents of Plaine Savo, a camp for internally displaced people in Djugu territory, Ituri Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo, were killed in a brutal mass stabbing carried out by CODECO militiamen. The attack, which occurred during the early hours of the day, has left the local community in shock and mourning. It is reported that around 4,000 people were living in the camp at the time of the attack. The incident is a stark reminder of the ongoing conflict and instability in the region and highlights the urgent need for a peaceful resolution.

UPDATE: Whaling in Iceland has a long history, dating back to the 12th century when it was primarily done through spear-drift hunting. Today, Iceland is one of the few countries that still maintains a whaling fleet and has been hunting fin whales for export to Japan. However, in a recent announcement, Iceland has stated that it will end the practice of whaling by 2024, citing the decreasing price of whale meat as the reason for this decision. This announcement comes after a temporary pause in whaling since 2019 due to coronavirus restrictions, competition from heavily subsidized Japanese whaling, and the growth of domestic whale watching tourism. Iceland's decision to end whaling is a significant step towards marine conservation and is sure to be welcomed by environmentalists worldwide.

The ongoing jihadist insurgency in Burkina Faso between the government and Islamist rebels has recently seen a battle between French troops and Ansar ul Islam leaving four civilians dead. The clash involved support from an attack helicopter and led to the killing of ten militants. The conflict, which has been ongoing since 2015 and is interpreted as part of the insurgency in the Maghreb, has resulted in a humanitarian crisis with thousands of people killed, displacement of civilians, and reports of war crimes and summary executions by both sides. Jihadists have also targeted schools and terrorized villagers during their everyday lives.

Canada has recently made changes to its mission in Ukraine under Operation Unifier. In a move that surprised many, the country withdrew military advisors from Ukraine and relocated them to an undisclosed location in Europe. Additionally, Canada moved its diplomatic staff to Lviv and suspended all operations at its embassy in Kyiv. Despite these changes, Canada has still committed to its broader mission under Operation Unifier, which includes helping the development of the region, maintaining security and democracy, providing humanitarian aid, and promoting economic stability and growth. The operation began in 2015 in coordination with the Ukrainian Armed Forces and also includes a small Swedish contingent. As of January 2022, there are 260 Canadian soldiers involved in providing training to Ukrainian troops, with more than 10,000 soldiers trained under Operation Unifier thus far.

The Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation is a European Union and Euratom regulation that allows the European Commission to take measures, including suspending payment of EU budget funds, against member states that violate the rule of law principles enshrined in article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. In recent years, concerns about democratic backsliding in Hungary and Poland have prompted the EU to take action. After years of stalling, the European Council and Parliament finally adopted the regulation in December 2020 with provisions that tie disbursements from the EU budget to adherence to rule of law standards. However, implementation has been delayed, with the European Council issuing declaratory statements in December 2020 addressing how the regulation should be implemented. The European Parliament has called on the Commission to avoid further delay in implementing the regulation, threatening legal action if necessary. Meanwhile, Hungary and Poland launched legal proceedings against the regulation, arguing it lacks a proper legal basis. However, on December 22nd, 2021, the European Court of Justice dismissed these challenges and confirmed the regulation's compliance with EU treaties, allowing the Commission to suspend EU budget funds to member states with rule of law issues affecting financial management.

The Australian government designates certain organisations as terrorist organisations, including Hamas (including its political wing), Atomwaffen Division, Tahrir al-Sham, and the Guardians of Religion Organization. This list of designated organisations is maintained by the Attorney-General's Department and enables the government to deal with organisations involved in terrorism. The Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002 inserted a range of terrorist organisation offences into the Criminal Code Act 1995, including making it an offence to materially support or be supported by a listed terrorist organisation. It is illegal to finance terrorism under Division 103 of the Criminal Code Act 1995, and the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) monitors financial transactions involving listed terrorist organisations. Australian anti-terrorism financing laws include sections such as 102.6, 102.7, 103.1, 103.2, and 119.4(5) of the Criminal Code Act 1995 and sections 20 and 21 of the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945. Prosecution of these offenses in Australia is overseen by the Australian Federal Police, State police forces, and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.
